What daily range is normal for a diabetic?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

â12-02-2012 08:53 PM

I'm getting frustrated with a daily range I can't get under, but my husband says maybe that's as good as can be expected, so please help us with a clarification of my blood count profile over a typical day.  I will preface the numbers by explaining that 2 months post diagnosis type two, I have reduced to normal weight range, have tweaked my diet to what seems ideal for me, have solved the dawn effect problem I experienced early on, power walk 45 minutes a day, have taken a diabetes class and take 1000 mg metformin every morning and 1000 mg every evening.  I don't slip, slide or backtrack--I'm disciplined since I have a goal of getting back to "normal range" without medication.  Having said all of that, with 4 tests a day (fasting morning, before lunch, before dinner and before the bedtime snack), I now seem "stuck" at the numbers I've gotten down to, which typically average about as follows over the day :  112, 120, 122, 115.  These individual numbers include, on the high end, an occasional frustrating (and inexplicable) "spike" to 150-160.  Yesterday's  numbers were:  104, 122, 146, 130.

 

I do not seek a "pat on the back" but rather would very much appreciate your 100% honest assessment of how these values compare to what one needs to do long term to preclude ill effects to health.

 

Thank you very much in advance!

 

Nojiko 

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: What daily range is normal for a diabetic?

Options

â12-02-2012 09:56 PM

What is your daily menu like? How many carbs are you eating each meal? Why are you only testing BEFORE meals and not after? Most of us here start testing at 1 and 2 hours after first bite of each meal to discover which foods cause spikes.  Some even discover their peak post-meal is at 90 mins.  Testing after the meal, and investigating/reducing carbs, will tell you why your numbers are stuck and help to get them down.

*********************************
You're among friends here!
*********************************
SugarFrosted aka AnnaM, retired ER/Oncology-Chemotherapy nurse
Little Rock, Arkansas
Diagnosed Type 2, Jun'09 at age 57
Jun'09 A1c: 7.2 F 154 wt 265 lbs
Dec'09 A1c: 5.5 F 80
Jun'10 A1c: 5.4 F 82
Dec'10 A1c: 5.2 F 71 wt 160 lbs
Jun'11 A1c: 5.3 F 76
Mar'12 A1c: 5.5 F 80
Dec'12 A1c: 5.1 F 70
Jan'14 A1c: 5.3 F 77
Aug'14 A1c: 5.4 F 78
Sep'15 A1c: 5.5 F 81
Reduced-Carb Mealplan & 1 hr Daily Exercise! NO Meds!
105 lb total weightloss
Self-employed baker/cake designer since 1988...life doesn't get much harder for a diabetic, imo. My Online Cake Gallery: http://www.sugarfrosted.com/

Re: What daily range is normal for a diabetic?

â12-03-2012 12:43 AM

nojiko wrote:

I'm getting frustrated with a daily range I can't get under, but my husband says maybe that's as good as can be expected, so please help us with a clarification of my blood count profile over a typical day.  I will preface the numbers by explaining that 2 months post diagnosis type two, I have reduced to normal weight range, have tweaked my diet to what seems ideal for me, have solved the dawn effect problem I experienced early on, power walk 45 minutes a day, have taken a diabetes class and take 1000 mg metformin every morning and 1000 mg every evening.  I don't slip, slide or backtrack--I'm disciplined since I have a goal of getting back to "normal range" without medication.  Having said all of that, with 4 tests a day (fasting morning, before lunch, before dinner and before the bedtime snack), I now seem "stuck" at the numbers I've gotten down to, which typically average about as follows over the day :  112, 120, 122, 115.  These individual numbers include, on the high end, an occasional frustrating (and inexplicable) "spike" to 150-160.  Yesterday's  numbers were:  104, 122, 146, 130.

 

I do not seek a "pat on the back" but rather would very much appreciate your 100% honest assessment of how these values compare to what one needs to do long term to preclude ill effects to health.

 

Thank you very much in advance!

 

Nojiko 

Hi Nojiko, welcome.

 

It can seem frustrating, especially when you don't have all of the information you need.  Testing before meals tells you nothing about how the meal effects your numbers nor if the carb count was too high.  Your before meal numbers are also pretty high, do you eat snacks?

 

Here's some advise I wrote to help people with testing, carbs, and meals:  click here.  Testing more for a time will help you see just what's going on.

 

Here's a list of suggested goals by agency:

 

 

RECOMMENDED BLOOD GLUCOSE GOALS

 

ADA:â¦â¦..A1Câ¦..<.7.0â¦.Fastingâ¦.90-130.â¦.PP*â¦â¦.<180

JOSLIN:....A1Câ¦..<7.0.â¦.Fastingâ¦.90-130.â¦.PP*â¦â¦.<160

AACE:â¦â¦A1Câ¦..<6.5..â¦Fastingâ¦â¦<110â¦...PP*â¦â¦.<140

NON-D:â¦.A1C...4.0-5.7.....Fastingâ¦..70-99â¦...PP**......70-120â¦**Non-diabetic

*ADA: âPost-prandial glucose measurements should be made 1â2 hours after the beginning of the meal, generally peak levels in patients with diabetes.â

ADA = American Diabetes Assn. Joslin = Joslin Diabetes Center AACE= American Association Of Clinical Endocrinologists

**Non-diabetic= ranges compiled from goals of all agencies.

 

Hang in there!

 

Lizzy

Knowledge is Power!

Re: What daily range is normal for a diabetic?

â12-03-2012 03:58 AM

nojiko wrote:

I'm getting frustrated with a daily range I can't get under, but my husband says maybe that's as good as can be expected, so please help us with a clarification of my blood count profile over a typical day.  I will preface the numbers by explaining that 2 months post diagnosis type two, I have reduced to normal weight range, have tweaked my diet to what seems ideal for me, have solved the dawn effect problem I experienced early on, power walk 45 minutes a day, have taken a diabetes class and take 1000 mg metformin every morning and 1000 mg every evening.  I don't slip, slide or backtrack--I'm disciplined since I have a goal of getting back to "normal range" without medication.  Having said all of that, with 4 tests a day (fasting morning, before lunch, before dinner and before the bedtime snack), I now seem "stuck" at the numbers I've gotten down to, which typically average about as follows over the day :  112, 120, 122, 115.  These individual numbers include, on the high end, an occasional frustrating (and inexplicable) "spike" to 150-160.  Yesterday's  numbers were:  104, 122, 146, 130.

 

I do not seek a "pat on the back" but rather would very much appreciate your 100% honest assessment of how these values compare to what one needs to do long term to preclude ill effects to health.

 

Thank you very much in advance!

 

Nojiko 

I think you're doing a great job, Nojiko.  When is your next A1c scheduled?  You will probably see for yourself at that time just how well you're doing.  If you want to get  your numbers down further, you may want to work some resistance training into your daily routine, in order to use some new and different muscles than your body is used to with the walking.  It doesn't take many reps with 5 and 6-pound dumbbells for me to "surprise" the muscles and drop my BG level lower than I usually get with walking, biking, or elliptical alone.  Other resistance moves work well, too: ab crunches, tricep dips, wall sit-squats, lunges, tricep dips, wall pushaways, extra stairclimbing, or just doing some step-ups on one step.  I get more mileage out of my regular exercise by throwing some of these in throughout the day.  (And evening.)

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

Re: What daily range is normal for a diabetic?

Options

â12-03-2012 11:16 AM

Thank you all so very much--you've come through for me again with great advice!  I'm feeling less frustrated now and much less "lost in the forest".   It's clear from Anna that I need to be testing again after meals...what was I thinking?  Anyway, getting that great summary of BG acceptable ranges from Lizzy was very helpful to give me the big picture, and your site, Lizzy, gives a lot of excellent information and advice.  The diet behind the numbers I gave is pretty similar to this one example:  Breakfast 1/2 c. low fat cottage cheese, 1 egg and coffee (1/2 decafe)--5 g. carbs;  Snack 1 slice of Wasa Crispbreak w no-salt peanut butter and 1/2 cup raw cauliflower w a little low fat Ranch dressing--7 g. carbs; Lunch 1/2 low carb tortilla + 1 siice Roma tomato, lettuce and 2 small pcs. organic chicken--3 g. carbs;  dinner 1/4 c. boiled garbanzo beans on mixed salad greens and green beans + 1 chicken burger--5 g. carbs;  evening snack (before bedtime) 2 "Ak-mak" sesame crackers with 1 T. almond butter--7 g. carbs.  For Alan's further information I vary the evening snack substituting 1 Laughting Cow Light cheese triangle or a slice of other low fat cheese for the almond butter, or some avocado (still with crackers).  Powerwalker, you've given me some great ideas about further exercise to target specific muscles as a way to improve numbers, and seeing what you do daily is an inspiration to anyone.

 

The nutritionist I took the class from keeps repeating "carbs are not your enemy", and recommends 120 carbs per day (to adequately feed the brain, she says).  As you can see my daily total (in this case around 30 total carbs) is FAR less than that.  Could any of you critique, advise or pass judgment on that?  I'm afraid that more carbs would raise my BG greatly.

 

Thanks again to all!

 

Nojiko 

Report Inappropriate Content

â12-03-2012 12:23 PM

nojiko wrote:

The nutritionist I took the class from keeps repeating "carbs are not your enemy", and recommends 120 carbs per day (to adequately feed the brain, she says).  As you can see my daily total (in this case around 30 total carbs) is FAR less than that.  Could any of you critique, advise or pass judgment on that?  I'm afraid that more carbs would raise my BG greatly.

 

Thanks again to all!

 

Nojiko 

 

I typically eat around 90 to 120 carbs per day as an active 48 year old guy. It has nothing to do with what any nutritionist, or anyone else, as hold told me to eat...it solely has to do with my meter says I can have As for how many carbs your brain needs, well your brain needs a very specific carb...glucose. It needs your BG levels to be within normal ranges, how you get your BG levels there is quite irrelevant

Thanks again to all!

 

Nojiko 

I agree with what Bill said.  Believe me there are many people here and on other sites that are apparently brain dead because they eat way less than 120 carbs a day!

 

Try the testing method and see just what your system can handle.  It's better to know than to guess.  The meter doesn't pass judgement, just tells it like it is. 

 

Lizzy

Knowledge is Power!
